Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Direct Search for Dark Matter with Underground Argon at LNGS
Award.AbstractNarration:
The existence of dark matter is inferred from gravitational effects, but its nature remains a deep mystery. One possibility, motivated by considerations in elementary particle physics, is that dark matter consists of the hypothesized Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs). It should be possible to detect WIMPs directly, as the orbital motion of the WIMPs composing the dark matter halo pervading the galaxy should result in WIMP-nucleus collisions of sufficient energy to be observable in the laboratory. This collaboration utilizes funds to commission and operate DarkSide-50, a WIMP search using a Liquid Argon Time Projection Chamber (LAr-TPC) with an active mass of 50 kg. DarkSide-50 will use argon extracted from underground sources (Underground Argon, UAr), which this group has shown to have an Ar-39 content lower, by at least a factor of 150, than atmospheric argon. Ar-39 is one of the main sources of background in the experiment.

A significant by-product of this group's research has been developing techniques that could find application in areas ranging from national security to medical imaging. This arises from the extraction of rare noble gases (Argon and Helium) from underground sources, and possible applications include the detection of underground nuclear tests and in Environmental Science where Argon is used as a detection media in ultra-low level proportional counter measurements for an environmental radio tracer for hydrologic transport.

Liquid argon is an attractive medium for WIMP detection due to its efficient conversion of energy from WIMP-induced nuclear recoils into both ionization and scintillation. The argon scintillation time profile ("pulse shape") depends on the type of ionizing particle, providing particle discrimination that can be used to suppress background. Pulse shape discrimination in argon provides one of the most powerful background rejections among all dark matter technologies; when combined with the measurement of ionization, the background rejection is further enhanced.

The proposed activity will advance the development of astroparticle physics and its scientific and educational mission by: (1) offering a continuing excellent opportunity for the training of students, who will contribute to the success of a cutting-edge project; (2) developing techniques that could find application in several areas of benefit to society; and (3) supporting a new education and outreach program, designed to succeed the highly successful Laboratori Nazionali del Gran Sasso-South Dakota-Princeton summer school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this collaborative research project is to conduct direct dark matter searches with the DarkSide-50 and DarkSide-20k detectors. The besides searching for dark matter, the DarkSide-50 project  made a scientific and technological demonstration proving it possible  to carry out dark matter search on argon target at 100-1000 tonne-year exposure free of backgrounds that could mimic dark matter signal.

 DarkSide-50 detector achieved this goal by performing a dark matter search with  with an atmospheric argon fill, registering no background events, setting the most sensitive dark matter search limit performed with an argon target.

Them DarkSide-50 detector was filled with argon from underground sources and thus much more sensitive search. Again, DarkSide-50 succeeded in carrying out background free search and setting a more sensitive limit to dark matter search. 

In a process DarkSide-50 demonstrated that the 39Ar activity in the underground argon extracted from the Cortez mine in Colorado is more than a factor 1,400 lower than that of atmospheric argon and as such suitable as a target in 100-ton scale detectors after additional purification of 40Ar from 39Ar.

Additionally, DarkSide-50 developed a method to search for light dark matter and set the best world limit on the dark matter with the mass in the range from 1.8-6 GeV/c^2.

University of Hawaii group led the calibration of the DarkSide-50 detector that validated detector performance and its capabilities to distinguish neutrons from electron like signals, since neutrons interact similar to dark matter particles. Calibration was also utilized to demonstrated the capabiites to veto neutrons and tag them not to be misidentified as dark matter particles. This was essential to demonstrate background free running of DarkSide-50.

As such DarkSide-50 enabled the development of the technology of LAr TPC with depleted argon fill, which was proven capable of running with extremely low background. This technology is well poised to be scaled to significantly larger detectors while maintaining the ability of running with a very low background;

With this project, the development of a new line of cryogenic photosensors based on silicon photomultipliers (SiPMs) has been initiated. We have recently demonstrates to surpass, in all technical marks for operation in the temperature range 70-90 Kelvin, the traditional photomultipliers tubes (PMTs), proven technology used since 1940-ies.

The availability of argon highly depleted from 39Ar has a positive impact on the following fields:

  • R&D for National-Security Missions - I: as part of the Proliferation Detection Program and the Nuclear Detonation Detection Program the Office of Defense Nuclear Nonproliferation Research and Development of the National Nuclear Security Administration (NNSA), Pacific Northwest National Laboratories (PNNL) and other laboratories routinely perform measurements of air samples collected around the world by the Air Force, looking for radioactive markers of nuclear detonation and/or nuclear fuel enrichment. The standard technique relies on low-background proportional tubes filled with P10 - a mix of argon (90% by volume) and methane (10% by volume). Following recent developments at PNNL resulting in abatement of background from the construction materials of said proportional tubes, 39Ar from atmospheric argon is now one of the leading sources of background. The use of underground argon will allow an enhancement of the sensitivity of proportional tubes, benefiting the larger goals of safeguard of NNSA. Kinder Morgan and Princeton University have entered into an agreement with PNNL to provide PNNL a few kg per year of underground argon to improve the NNSA effort on nuclear nonproliferation and security;

  • Environmental Science and Global Climate Change: argon is used as a detection media in internal-source gas proportional counting of isotopes useful as environmental radiotracers. Its role is very important in understanding the ocean currents [Oceanographers in noble pursuit, Nature News, January 2002] and especially in understanding the main element of the thermohaline ocean circulation, the so-called Great Conveyor Belt [Nature 421, 699 (2003)]. The DarkSide collaboration has developed the most sensitive method to date for dating of 39Ar [arxiv:1204.6011]. In addition, underground argon from Cortez is as of today the best blank for calibration of other lab methods for 39Ar dating, such as Atom Trap Trace Analysis (ATTA) [PRL 106, 103001 (2011)] and direct counting [Earth Planet. Sci. Lett. 63, 51 (1983)], actively in use for climate research. Kinder Morgan and Princeton University have entered into an agreement with two of the leading groups of the field, at University of Bern and University of Heidelberg, to provide the underground argon required for the blank of their ATTA and direct counting detectors.
